speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (12.04 P.m.)
theText: I welcome the opportunity to comment on theMC 2214 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 June 1995 Dr Blewett, which I think have very much enhanced the workings of the parliament. I have only been here a relatively short time-a couple of years-but I certainly believe that, in general, those reforms have been very positive. In an overall sense, the comments that are in this report under the auspices of the committee now chaired by the honourable member for Charlton( Mr Robert Brown) are very worthwhile. I refer to a number of the specific themes that are mentioned in the report and add my views to some of the things that have been mentioned by the honourable member for Cowper( Mr Nehl) and some of the previous speakers. Firstly, it is fairly widely recognised that this Main Committee has been a successful innovation within the proceedings of the parliament. The comments in the report indicate that the Main Committee should be continued as an integral part of the process of debate, consideration. of reports, legislation and the like. I would certainly endorse that and endorse the comments that the honourable member for Cowper made in that regard. I note the comments that were made in the report with respect to the public gallery and the need to take steps to encourage visitors to parliament to come and watch the proceedings of the Main Committee as well as the proceedings of the House itself. It is fortunate that the members of the committee did not go into any detail about the types of initiatives that we might want to pursue in that regard: perhaps a hot dog stand or one or two other things might assist. But I think it is important to keep these things in perspective-that people do come to see the proceedings of the chambers of the parliament for reasons other than just seeing politicians. It is ultimately the base of our democratic system of government and there is a certain symbolism associated with seeing the parliament, in seeing the House of Representatives, which clearly is not replicated within the Main Committee because the Main Committee is simply an adjunct to the House of Representatives. Whether we like it or not, I think that this Main Committee will always be something of a poor cousin to the House of Representatives. Therefore we should not concern ourselves unduly with the lack of attendance and the fact that today, in spite of the fact that I am doing my best to make a good contribution, we have only got a couple of people sitting opposite in the seats available for the public. The second point to which I wish to advert is the issue of question time. Both the rostering system and the timing of question time are raised in the report. With respect to the timing matter, I am something of an agnostic. I think that the later time of question time is marginally better for backbenchers in terms of the various other obligations that backbenchers have. I really do not have a particularly strong view about the alternative that has been put forward of 2.30 p.m. rather than 3 p.m. However, I do have a couple of views about the question of rostering. One recommendation that is put forward is that the opposition be entitled to demand the presence of one minister at any question time, obviously in order to ensure that, where there is a particular issue running and a particular minister is under pressure, that minister cannot hide behind the fact of not being on a roster on the particular day. This is probably a reasonable suggestion, but it needs to be kept in mind that ministers do other things; they do have other responsibilities. Part of the difficulty in pursuing this suggestion is that we would need to ensure that ministers actually had some notice that they were going to be required to attend question time. Otherwise they would not be able to schedule alternative commitments: meetings with delegations, functions and the like. In a Thursday, 22 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2215 sense, the more notice we require the opposition to give a particular minister, the more we defeat the purpose of the exercise in the first place. It then becomes very difficult for the opposition to know two or three days in advance that a particular minister is going to be targeted at a particular question time. Of course, it forces them to telegraph their punches, in a sense, as to what type of theme they are going to be running in question time. In essence, it is a worthwhile and constructive suggestion, and I think that the spirit of the suggestion is very logical and fair, but some further work on the detail may be necessary in order to work up an appropriate proposal. I should add that, in a sense, some of the criticisms that are made of the new system of question time by the opposition really only have value because it has failed to make use of the opportunities, by and large, that are offered by the new arrangements. One of the opportunities that is offered by the new arrangements is the ability to concentrate on particular lower profile ministers in more junior ministries, to really give them a hammering and put them under some pressure, to test just how much they are on top of their portfolios and to see whether they are fully across the difficult issues that might be pertinent at the time. In spite of those opportunities, the opposition, in my observation, has not yet taken that option. It has not been able to make use of that. I think the opposition would find that it would get greater value out of the new question time arrangements if it started to pay a bit more attention to some of the ministers who very rarely get asked questions by the opposition. I think the statistics would show that a large number of ministers have barely been asked a question by the opposition in the time that this parliament has sat-maybe one or two, but certainly not very many-and that they tend to rely on government backbenchers to ask questions, to keep them occupied in question time. The next issue I refer to is sitting hours. I have some sympathy with the honourable member for Cowper about the question of being able to get home on Thursday night. I am certainly of the view that we should conduct our arrangements in such a way as to enable pretty well all honourable members to get home on Thursday night. To me, the great advance made by the reforms under the Blewett committee was to enable the vast majority of honourable members to get home on Thursday night. It means for me that I can now work a normal Friday rather than wandering around in a semi-comatose state, unable to do much more than sign correspondence and look at things coming across my in-tray. unfortunately my best years are already well behind me. Mr Robert Brown-No, ahead of you. member for Cowper. To me, if we are faced with a choice of extra hours on the Thursday evening or, for example, sitting till 9 or 10 o'clock on the Tuesday evening or the Wednesday evening, it is much more logical to sit later on the evenings when we are required to be in Canberra in any event. It is also worth pointing out that we have actually saved the taxpayer a bit of money by enabling honourable members to leave on Thursday night, because there is one less day for which people will claim travel allowance. We have also ensured that honourable members are able to spend a slightly greater amount of time with their families, which is ultimately a fairly important question.

I do have some sympathy with the view of the honourableMC 2216 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 June 1995 I have some sympathy with the honourable member for Perth( Mr Stephen Smith), when he refers to the speeches by the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard), with respect to the republic and to the budget, which twice now we have had to have on the Thursday night. This has forced honourable members either to delay their return home until the following morning or to go through some rather bizarre travel arrangements in order to get home late on Thursday night. I would not mind that quite so much if there were any content in what the Leader of the Opposition said in his speeches. Unfortunately, in the one on the republic he took 30 minutes to say what anybody could have said in about three minutes, and his speech on the budget was essentially rhetoric with no specific propositions about alternatives, about what the opposition would do if it were in government. If there were a greater degree of substance in the speeches I would perhaps not quite mind so much, but to stay back to listen to vacuous nonsense is a bit irritating, to say the least. I would say as an observation on this question of sitting times, schedules and so forth that I am an opponent of the parliament sitting more. It is a mistake that people in the community often make, to assume that the only real or important work that parliamentarians do is actually being in parliament and sitting. In fact, it is probably less important than the work that parliamentarians do in their constituency. It would worry me that, if we spent more time here, we of all political persuasions would end up being more remote, less in touch with our electors and less in touch with what is going on at the grassroots level in our electorates. Ultimately what we do, day in, day out, when we are not in parliament, is go around our electorates, be at functions, deal with problems and talk to constituents, delegations and the like. To me that is probably the paramount role of a parliamentarian. Certainly for a backbencher it is the paramount role. To impinge on that for the purposes of longer sittings is wrong. Ultimately it has a undemocratic impact, in that we are less representative of the people who have actually elected us to be here. The role of parliament is touched on in this report. A commentator a couple of years ago made an observation that parliament in our system is now little more than an electoral college that every two or three years elects an executive and then wallows in irrelevance. I think that is probably being a bit harsh, but there is a certain degree of substance to that. In a sense it reflects the increasing complexity of government. The emergence of parliamentary committees to some extent reflects those changes, so that a lot of the detailed action in consideration of legislation occurs less often in the chambers of parliament than perhaps it once did. SoI think we all have a lot of thinking to doA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 12.16 p.m. to 12.28 p.m. and its relationship to the executive. One of the things we could look at is how we seem to spend an enormous amount of time debating bills that involve minor, fairly technical amendments to legislation where we have to use the legislation as, in a sense, a heading to enable us to debate broader issues. I suppose there is a necessity for that, but, on some occasions, it also involves the whips of all the major parties asking people to speak and, therefore, to fit themselves into a fairly artificial structure of debate. Our democracy would be much better suited if we were able to have substantive debates in the parliament on the key issues that face the nation rather than having to modify what we

theText: Before the suspension, I was making reference to the workings of parliamentThursday, 22 June 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2217 are saying and how we are saying it in order to fit in with, say, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995 or whatever the case may be. Obviously, we still need to debate all of those technical amendments to legislation and so forth, but I am sure that we could do that in a much shorter time. Consideration of this reform of the parliament may, in future, be taken up by the Standing Committee on Procedure. The final comment I make relates to the scheduling of parliamentary sessions. I am very pleased to see that I scored a footnote in the committee's report as a result of my brief submission and that relates to the fact that of the budget, we now have three major breaks in the parliamentary calendar. The winter break is relatively unchanged-roughly seven weeks-but, because of the need to have a substantial break prior to the budget in order to allow ministers to prepare for the budget, the summer break has been shortened. This has led to a rather ridiculous situation where parliament is resuming sitting later in January. It is absurd that we should all be going back home to shiver in our electorates, those of us who do not go overseaswhen we could actually be sitting here for at least some of that time, and yet we are coming here late in January. One of the reasons this can cause problems for members-not that any of us are still likely to be on holidays late in January-is that I find that to come cold back to work and start sitting straight away is often a problem. We get a little build-up of work over the Christmas-New Year period that we have to deal with and it is certainly better to be able to have a week or two of working in the electorate office before the House starts sitting. I would normally return to work about that time in January so perhaps it is not such a huge problem. I do think that the recommendation the committee has made, that we start sitting on the first Tuesday in February rather than late January, is a sensible one. It gives a little more flexibility at a time of the year when it is better to be away from this place than it is during winter. I also support the committee's recommendation that we should always sit on Mondays, with one exception. I think that is a sensible suggestion. It gets more value out of a week. It ensures that, if we are coming here, we actually get some substantial value from what we are doing and we do not lose a day for no particular reason other than that it is the start of a session. speaker: Mr Bradford (Mcpherson) (12.31 P.m.)
theText: I would like to make a few remarks as oneMC 2218 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 June 1995 many committees. We cannot be everywhere. I am certainly very keen for the committee to continue its work. I think those of us who have been here for some time have lots of ideas about how the parliament can be improved. I suspect the enthusiasm for change-I am not sure; the chairman might tell me-is probably greater on the opposition side than it is on the government side. That would probably be the case no matter who was in government or who was in opposition. Plainly, to a large extent the opposition bears the brunt of the government's decisions in respect of these practices. The government simply has the numbers. In the end, the parliament survives, I suppose, largely because of the conventions and a certain amount of goodwill that exists between the two sides. There are a number of issues raised in this report that require ongoing consideration. I am sure that that is recommended and that there will be an ongoing process of consideration. I am one who is concerned about question time. I think all of us are: on our side, perhaps for different reasons. It is a pity that question time reflects so badly on us all as members. From our constituents, and particularly from school groups that come here, we all get tarred with the brush that is used in question time, that we are all a mob of louts. I try to explain to people-I am sure we all do-that question time is a smaIl part of the day. It is always going to be an active part. It is in the House of Lords; it is in every parliament of the world. I suppose to some extent it gives the opposition a good opportunity to make points, one way or another, in the form of the questions that it asks. In the end, the true purpose of question time ought to be as it is defined, to seek information and to have information provided. I understand that that is its purpose. I think the culture has to change. We can talk about changing the rules as far as the Speaker's independence is concerned, but in the end there has to be an attitude by the government-and, hopefully, by us, if we were in government-that that is the purpose of question time, and that ministers will be required to answer questions and know more. The practice of ministers going off, as they inevitably do, to talk about what the opposition did 10 or 20 years ago, or to make a personal attack on the person who has asked the question, is not the intention. If we were in government, I think we would still find it a temptation to do that, but I am hoping that we would not do so. The chairman of the committee, the member for Charlton( Mr Robert Brown) has been here a lot longer than I have, and maybe it is a bit unrealistic of me to expect that to happen. As my colleague who spoke a moment ago said, very often they ought to be matters of debate, as they are the sort of things we ought to be doing in the parliament. If something is important enough for a minister to get up and talk for 10 or 15 minutes, then he ought to do it. There are plenty of places for him to do it, and I would encourage that. The answer to question time is an attitudinal and cultural thing, and I would like to think that, in government, we would fix question time up in that way, without tinkering around with it and trying to make it work by putting bandaids on it instead of making an actual cultural change. Sure, it depends a lot on the Speaker and the Speaker's independence, and I certainly would not want to cast aspersions on the current Speaker or on any other, because I think it is improper to do that. Obviously, I would like to somehow see the word 'relevant' defined. The Speakers keep throwing it back on the parliament to define it. Maybe it is a difficult thing, but the word has a literal meaning. My experience in the parliament is that, clearly, ministers are very often irrelevant, except in the absolutely broadest interpretation of what 'relevance' actually means. That needs to be fixed, and I challenge the government to define what is relevant. I know the Procedure Committee has considered in the past whether time limits ought to be applied, and that is another thing that has been done in the Senate. The Main Committee is one of the beneficial changes that came into being. The other beneficial change is standing committees. The House of Representatives committee system provides backbenchers with a meaningful role in the parliament and this situation is as a result of the goodwill between the government and the opposition members on the committees and because these committees operate a little bit differently. Many of the reports which are brought back to the parliament are unanimous reports, and that aspect helps. As Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I am in a position to know that that committee has received the bulk of references in terms of advisory reports. If success can be measured in terms of the government picking up recommendations, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has achieved a substantial success rate. There have been some controversial pieces of legislation referred to the committee, and the way the legislation has been dealt with is a credit to the cooperation of the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Tangney( Mr Williams), the honourable member for Holt( Mr Duffy), the honourable member for Jagajaga( Mr Staples) and the other members of the committee. Proper resourcing of the secretariat and secondment of officers from the department to assist in specialist reports are the keys to the success of the committee. This situation has resulted in alterations which enrich the legislation which originates in the House of Representatives. We need government and opposition members to resist the push by the Executive for urgent consideration of this legislation. My view has always been that if the legislation that has been introduced by the Executive into the parliament is so crash hot it will withstand scrutiny by members of the parliament and by members of the public. In some instances there will be policy differences, and that is when a number of the recommendations may not be taken up. But in the short time that the committees have been operating the parliament has received reports that not only withstand scrutiny but are gaining international recognition. The reports of the legal committee on the child sex tourism bill and the war crimes bill, as I understand it, have been considered model reports, and members of the parliament in New Zealand and other parliaments are using them as a basis of legislation in those countries. I think that says something about the potential for the operation of those committees. One of the underutilised areas of the committees is our ability-and it is pointed out on page 18 of this report-pursuant to the standing orders, to examine annual reports of government departments. Parliamentary committees, particularly in the House, need to do that a bit more often because that is another useful mechanism for suggesting change to the Executive. There is nothing wrong with reviewing an annual report of the director of public prosecutions or the ombudsman, for instance, by bringing them before the committee and going through how the legislation might currently be working. The committees could bring forward reports to the Executive suggesting areas of change. backbench member of parliament on either side can make a substantial contribution. On the matter of rostering, there is a comment in this report that there has been criticism of the present roster system. Opposition members of the committee expressed a strong view that the roster should be abandoned, that is, in relation to the roster of ministers for question time. The truth is that there are members of the government who are not well disposed to the rostering system. It is a matter of public record that I was one in caucus who felt that the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) should be at question time every day. I expressed that view because I believe that he is a master in that forum; that he is the equivalent of what Bradman was to cricket when it comes to question time in the parliament; and that it was absurd to select someone like Bradman in a side as captain and then say that because of his outstanding performances and to even up the score he had better go and sign a few signatures out in the paddock and be used for only part of the time. That is my particular view.

The overwhelming view on our side of the parliament is that the roster system has proved beneficial. I think what has happened is that the members of the opposition, quite frankly, have not taken the benefits that they should from the roster. They still need to learn a little about tactics and how to launch an offensive, and this rhetoric about 'Yes, we want the Prime Minister back in question time every day'Mr Robert Brown-No, they don't. it is a disadvantage, from this government's point of view, when he is not there because of his total dominance. Frankly, I like him in question time because I think that it shows how he is so dominant and why he is the best person in that position, at this point of time, that this country has to offer and that this parliament has to offer. We only have to look at the galleries at question time-both the public gallery and the press gallery-because when the Prime Minister is not there the galleries are empty. When he is there they are all there, they are all filled. It is an electric atmosphere, it is a charged atmosphere. But that is one where I do not have the numbers. We will still work on it, though. The operation of the sin-bin is on page 28 of this report. Question time is theatre, and we are all guilty of participating. I suppose the truth is that, in terms of government members, I would probably be one of the more culpable ones in terms of the interchange and in being quite vociferous from the backbench, because I do not believe in sitting idle on the backbench when the members of the opposition are in the fray. There is only one way: we have got to give it back to them. If we are fair dinkum in terms of the operation of the sin-bin and if it is what we want-total decorum and total silence when a question is asked or when a minister is answering a question or when the Prime Minister is answering a question-then I say to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker that they should exercise the sin-bin a lot more harshly and a lot more often than they do. I think that if there were two or three days in succession where the Speaker or Deputy Speaker, whichever is in charge, threw out three or four government members and three or four opposition members-quite frankly, under the present standing orders that is possible, and I would say that I would probably be the first government member to be thrown out, because I have been given a bit of leniency-then we would get a question time where we could hear a pin drop. But is that what we really want? The truth is that in our heart of hearts most of us do not. I find question time the most engaging and enjoyable part of the operation of the parliament and it is the most electric when the Prime Minister is there. I am not saying that as one who is one of the mates of the Prime Minister-my views are well known in relation to that. It is a balance. So let us not get on with the humbug. I think the power is there. I actually enjoy the interchange between government and opposition members, but I do believe that there are times when that power should be exercised a bit more. I think that the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker have shown enormous tolerance to us as members of the parliament. The other matter, which I will finish with, concerns the hours of sitting.
